sources.title: "Girls Winding Armatures" (1904) cinematographer Billy Bitzer
sources.description: This gem is presented by Silent Hall of Fame.   Please visit https://silent-hall-of-fame.org/   to support our non-profit mission and the legacy of silent movie stars by making a tax deductible contribution.   FEEL FREE TO FOLLOW US ON TWITTER @SilentFilmGems   "Girls Winding Armatures" is a very short documentary.  The film is included in our program to illustrate the work of Billy Bitzer, a star of Silent Hall of Fame. The film is part of the series "Westinghouse Works" (1904), which was added to the National Film Registry in 1998 as being deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant". Let's all give our thanks to the Library of Congress for preserving this film and making it available to the public. Directed by                       unknown Cinematography by         Billy Bitzer Starring                             unknown Distributed by                   Biograph Company Release date                      May 6, 1904 Country                             United States Running time                    2 m.   Copyright Disclaimer Under Section 107 of the Copyright Act 1976: "Allowance is made for "fair use" for purposes such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, and research. Fair use is a use permitted by copyright statute that might otherwise be infringing. Non-profit, educational or personal use tips the balance in favor of fair use."

metadata.Plot: Numerous women sit in rows at machines where they appear to be winding some type of wire and tooling it onto machines. Two young men push spools of this wire down the aisle. Supervisors, male and female, walk down the aisle and observe the women's work, stopping for a while at one woman's station.
